CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Reference attached voucher number 309 in favour of Home Oil Distributors Limited, it was necessary to arrange for berge delivery of a quantity of fuel oil for the heater and range in the Homalco day school and attached teacher's residence, to avoid a winter shortage of supply.

Hitherto oil was obtained by the barrel from Stuart Island, as there is now no boat service to Church House.

The oil had to be freighted by the Indians by small boat to Church House and difficulties were continually encountered in maintaining supply.

(H. F. Taylor),
Indian Superintendent.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of Departmental telegram dated Sept. 18th, in which the Department offers per capita grant, plus $50.00, and in addition the necessary books for High School, on receipt of requisition, in the case of the Indian child Peter Rivers, who had recently passed the Entrance Examination, for the High School.

In this connection, I beg to say that in the case of the half-breed, it is probable that he will be taken care of at the expense of the rate-payers, at North Vancouver, by arrangement with the Board of School Trustees.

On the 19th instant, Mr. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools, and I visited the Squamish Mission Reserve and interviewed the parents of the Indian boy, Peter Rivers, to see if the parents would be willing to make up the difference between the grant offered by the Department and the fees demanded by the School Trustees and after consideration, the parents have decided that instead of letting this boy attend High School they will have him go to work.

I would add that in my former communication I referred to this boy as being a pupil of the Indian School, but I later ascertained that the boy is a day school scholar, attending the classrooms in the boarding school, set apart for Indian Day School purposes. The per capita grant, therefore, in his case, which the Department offers to pay, would not apply to this boy.

I have suggested to the Board of School trustees that if they would be willing to accept the fee of $50.00 offered by the Department, with free books, the parents may be induced to allow the boy to attend High School.

Your obedient servant,

C.C. Ferry,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

I have been instructed by the School Board of this District to make enquiry from you with regard to the education of six white children who are living on the Capilano Indian Reserve, North Vancouver, B.C.

This reserve is situated just outside the boundaries of our Municipality and within the Municipality of West Vancouver. The children are not near any West Vancouver School, and have been allowed to attend one of our schools which is convenient for them. Now we find that we have not sufficient accommodation for them and West Vancouver refuses to take care of them on the ground that the land on which they live pays no school taxes.

These people are living on the reserve on land leased from the Indians or the Indian Department, we are told. It therefore appears to my Board that the Indian Department should provide for their education. It seems reasonable for West Vancouver to refuse to take them in when they do not pay school taxes, and of course it is out of the question to expect my Board to do so when they are not in our District.

Your kind consideration of this matter and an early reply will be much appreciated. Meantime we are continuing to look after the children's education.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Secretary to the Board.
October 12th, 1925.

Dear Sir,

I have your 4-47 of the 29th ultimo with reference to grants for two pupils who are attending the High School at North Vancouver. I note that one boy is a half-breed and the Department of course cannot give tuition grants for pupils who are not clearly our wards.

I note that Peter Rivers in whose connection the Department offered a grant of $50.00 is not a pupil of the Squamish Indian Residential School. This alters the case somewhat and as you appear to be interested in this lad's future, the Department would increase the grant to $75.00 for the academic year if the parents decide to have him attend High School.

Yours truly,

J.D. McLean,

The girl, being an Indian, is deprived of all privileges extended to white children; we could not even bring them to curtail the fees.

Hoping, dear Sir, that these lines shall be taken into consideration, I remain

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge Departmental letter No. 103-167, dated September 19th., with reference to the tuition grant of the Department to assist Florence Thomas, a pupil of Squamish Indian Residential School, to take a commercial course at the City of North Vancouver High School.

In reply I have the honour to inform the Department that during negotiations with the Department the Reverend Bishop in charge of the Indian School made arrangements for the admission of the girl to the City of North Vancouver High School to enter upon a two-year commercial course, for which the girl is thought to have inclination and ability, and I have received from the Secretary of the Board of School Trustees an account for the first quarterly term, September 6th. to November 15th., 1927, in the sum of $28.75, voucher for which, No. 2712, is herewith transmitted to the Department.

In this connection I would inform the Department that I have discussed with the School Trustees the question as to payment by the Department for tuition fees in view of the fact that the Residential School is located within the City, and the Department has assumed payment to the Municipality of school taxes amounting to 10 mills in behalf of this institution. In doing so I had in view the information conveyed to me that pupils of the Coqualeetza Residential School at nearby are admitted to High School in the Town of Chilliwack free of tuition fees. The Board of School Trustees holds the view that it is evident that the Squamish Residential School is operated for monetary consideration along the lines of any business undertaking and that if the point raised by me was seriously considered it might follow that any person, firm or organization conducting business within the City and paying Municipal taxes on property used for business purposes must likewise be possessed of transferable rights in respect to the educational facilities of the public schools:

schools; also that to admit free of charge any one pupil of Squamish Residential School to the City High School would establish a precedent entitling all children who are inmates of the same institution to the privileges of the public schools of the City. Similar treatment could not then be denied all private boarding schools. Thus, the owners of such institutions would be enabled to dispense with the teaching staff and operate their establishments with domestic help only while bringing in children from outside territory and deriving a profit on their education obtained at the expense of the local ratepayers.

It is quite probable that the Department has already given consideration to the foregoing question and, assuming it has done so and has decided notwithstanding the question in point to contribute to the tuition fees of pupils attending High School in the same City where the Indian Residential School is situated and where school taxes are paid by the Department, the account of the School Board has been certified for payment.

The tuition fee of the North Vancouver High School is $115.00 per year and the Reverend Sisters in arranging with the School Board for quarterly payments did so with a view of terminating the High School course for the girl in the event of it being found that the Department would not be prepared to meet the cost of the girl's tuition at High School.

Accounts for succeeding quarters are expected to be received from the School Board unless any further question should arise in connection therewith.

Your obedient servant,

I would further recommend that the grant be paid from the $100,000 appropriation set aside for Indian advancement by the Government through the Parliamentary Committee.

Sir:

I have received a request from an Indian girl Florence Thomas, aged 19, of the Burrard No.3 Band for assistance in completing a stenographic course. She has had two years Commercial Course at the North Vancouver High School but cannot obtain suitable employment until she has had this further instruction to improve her shorthand and typewriting speed. Florence Thomas is an orphan. She assists in supporting her younger brother and sisters and appears to be in earnest in her efforts to improve her earning capacity. If the necessary funds are available, I respectfully recommend that this assistance be granted. The fees at the nearest place of instruction, viz. the Lonsdale Shorthand & Typewriting Academy, North Vancouver, B.C., are $17.50 per month and the girl would be able to live at her home on the Reserve while attending school.

Dear Sir:

I beg to apply on behalf of the above named ex-pupil of the Squamish Indian School for assistance to enable him to take a year's high school course at St. Edmund's School, North Vancouver, with a view to entering Technical School later if he becomes qualified.

The Reverend Principal of the Squamish Indian School has requested that we do something for this boy as we have not in recent years assisted any of their ex-pupils.

I have interviewed the boy whose father is not working and in receipt of relief intermittently. I am not particularly impressed with the boy but possibly his contact with white boys at high school will improve him.

I beg to advise that Mr. Paul, of the Sechelt Band, has requested assistance in sending his son, Henry Paul, to the Vancouver Technical School to study gas engine mechanics. He has made arrangements to pay for the boy's maintenance, if we will pay the school expenses.

The training so far has been given free, and I believe there will be no change in this policy. All we are asked to do is to provide tools and stationery.

Henry Paul is 15 years old, and was formerly in Sechelt Residential School. He is a particularly fine-looking lad, and his parents are hardworking Indians, his father being a logger. The mechanical training is to enable the boy to obtain work on a fish-packing boat as engineer. Indians with experience of this kind are usually given preference on these boats which often have Indian crews entirely.

I am advised by the School that expenses for the mechanical training are kept very low as most of the boys would be unable to obtain the training otherwise.

I respectfully request that you authorize this in the case of Henry Paul. I should add that his board and incidental expenses, paid by his father, will amount to about $25.00 or $30.00 per month.

Sir:

re: File No.103-167.

I beg to enclose herewith vouchers for School fees and materials at the Vancouver Technical School for Henry Paul, of the Sechelt Band.

This boy attended the technical school for one year, his father paying his board in town and your letter of October 4th, 1937, authorized some necessary school supplies. The expense to the boy's father has been quite a heavy drag on him, and I do not think Henry has warranted the expense. For a few months he was quite studious, but later took no interest in his studies, and the proprietor of his boarding house said he was behaving badly. The School authorities advised me they thought he was wasting his time as he stayed at school only as an excuse to be in town. He has now returned to his Reserve.

I was surprised to receive the enclosed account for tuition, as we have put a number of pupils through the Technical School during the past 10 years, without charge, but I am now advised that they are compelled to charge under Section 138, of the School Act. The following is a copy of the School Board's letter:

"It is quite true that we did not bill you in previous years for Indian students who came to Vancouver to reside and attended school for the reason that Section 138 of the School Act defined these children as residents. This Act was changed at the 1937 session of the legislature as follows: 'For the purpose of this Act, a pupil whose parents or guardian reside elsewhere shall not be deemed to be a resident in a school district or municipality by reason only of the fact that the pupil boards at a boarding-house in the School district or municipality, unless he is a pupil whose parents or guardian reside in a part of the Province not comprised within the limits of a school district.' The amendment of said Section 138 enacted by this section shall come into operation on the last day of July 1938."

Therefore, I presume the account must be paid.

I have the honour to be,

B/DH.

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I wish to place the following facts before you for consideration. An Indian of the Squamish Band, No.171, Simon Baker, who has six children, two of school age, has been sending them to the Lower Capilano public school in the District of North Vancouver. The District has advised him that he is living in the Municipality of West Vancouver, and therefore they cannot accept his children in the District school unless he pays $5.00 per month for each child.

Baker lives on Capilano Indian Reserve (Squamish No.5) and is only a few feet from the boundary of the District and the Municipality of West Vancouver, whose schools are several miles from Baker's home. The children cannot attend the Squamish Indian Day School, as it is also too far, and they are not Roman Catholic, Baker does not wish them to attend Squamish Indian Residential School. Even if they did attend the latter school, it would cost us more than $5.00 each per month, and the school is filled up anyway.

Baker now requests that the Department will pay this charge for him. There are not enough children on Capilano Reserve to open a day school for Protestant children. One family has moved to Squamish I.R.No.1 at North Vancouver so that their children can attend public school, but Baker cannot do that.

Seeing that we are paying quite a large grant to Residential and Day Schools in this Agency, which are all Roman Catholic, I hope the Department can see its way clear to do this much for the Protestant Squamish Indians, a number of whom (including Simon Baker) attended Lytton Anglican Residential School. Your advice at an early date will be appreciated, as the public schools re-open on May 3rd.

Indian Agent.

B/DH.
Ottawa

Mr. F.J.C. Ball, Indian Agent, 416 Federal Bldg.,

Re: Simon Baker, No. 171, Squamish Band

I have for acknowledgment your air mail letter of the 28th instant, in which you submit for Departmental consideration a request received by you for a grant necessary to enable the children of the marginally-noted Indian to attend the Lower Capilano Public School.

Inasmuch as requests such as this may reach you from time to time, may I explain how our educational appropriations are now voted by Parliament. These appropriations consist of two main items:

1. Grants to Indian residential schools;
2. Indian day school teachers' salaries.

Under existing regulations these funds cannot be used for any other purpose and are voted separately by Parliament. This fact leaves us with a comparatively small amount of money for tuition and other grants. It is exceedingly difficult, therefore, for us to make a grant such as the one suggested, particularly in view of the fact that no provision has been made for it in the 1943-44 estimates.

In view of your recommendation, however, we are prepared to make a grant for the coming academic term which, I notice, commences on May 3. The claims of these children for a continuance of this grant and the conditions in which they find themselves should be carefully reviewed at the close of the school year. It is just possible, of course, that Simon Baker, in
the meantime, may change his place of residence. In any event it would be appreciated if a report on the case reached us prior to the preparation of the 1944-45 estimates.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

re: File No.103-167

I beg to refer to your letter of the 30th April last regarding grant for the children of Simon Baker, No.171, of the Squamish Band, to attend public school. Your decision to make a grant for the term commencing May 3rd was much appreciated, but, unfortunately, could not be taken advantage of.

The City of North Vancouver had an unpaid bill of $50.00 against Simon Baker for a period during which the children attended school before they found out that he was not living in that municipality. Baker could not pay this amount, and the City therefore refused to accept the children for the term commencing May 3rd, although I assured them that we would pay for this term.

The children did not attend school, therefore, and the only tuition they received was from their parents, which was not very much. I could not ask the Department to pay this outstanding bill, and the matter rested there. I am reporting the above facts with a view to receiving your advice.

Baker says he will try to pay up the $50.00 before school re-opens, but he feels rather badly about the fact that other parents on the Reserve hand over their children to the Residential School for the Department to support for ten years whereas all he asks is assistance in paying only for their tuition. If an amount could be placed in the 1944-5 Estimates as mentioned in your letter, it would be appreciated. This case is uncommon in this Agency, although no doubt it is common enough in many other places.

Indian Agent.

Request for Educational Assistance.

Edward Guerin, father of the above Indian, has applied for assistance in providing him with a nine months business course in typing and bookkeeping.

William Guerin was born September 7th, 1930. He entered a Catholic School when nine years old and was advanced three grades in his first year. After a year's absence from school through illness he passed the eighth grade. In September 1946 he entered grade nine in Vancouver College, being apparently under the impression that a course in typing and bookkeeping was available. When he found that this course was not taught he lost interest and discontinued attending.

Edward Guerin, the father, works as a fish buyer. He has a boat and is now building a second one for use in his business. However, in order to build he has had to pledge the bulk of his earnings for a year or more ahead. He is illiterate and finds it a big handicap in business, and the son William wants a business course in order to be able to handle his father's accounting and correspondence.

The Principal of Vancouver College advises that William should do well in such a course. He is undoubtedly bright and has ambition, and as a business course may enable the family to eventually carry on a good business, I would recommend that the Department provide the necessary fees.

The Sprott Shaw Business College, 30 minutes by streetcar from the Guerin home offer a nine month course in typing, cost accounting and junior bookkeeping for $2.00 monthly. The classroom hours are 9 to 12 and 1 to 3.30. A commercial course in a high school requires three years. From inquiries made I am satisfied that the parents are not at present financially able to provide the tuition.

I consider this is a case that merits encouragement and assistance.

(H. E. Taylor),
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, February 7, 1948.

Mr. H.E. Taylor, Indian Agent, 416 Federal Building,
Vancouver, British Columbia.

We have received the December Quarter Return of the Sechelt United School. It is noted that this Return includes the name of Theresa Jeffries. In this connection I attach a copy of a letter which was forwarded to Major MacKay on October 16, 1947. Is this girl staying at the Sechelt Residential School?

We do not appear to have had any previous correspondence re Normal Joseph whose name is also shown on the December Return from the Sechelt United School. Why is it necessary for him to attend a White School? Could he not attend the Squamish School?

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Indian Affairs Branch,

OTTAWA.

Attention: Supt. of Indian Education:

Dear Sir:

Reference yours of February 7, 1948, regarding Theresa Jeffries, I would advise that this girl is taking a high school course at the Sechelt Superior (or United) School.

She is in residence at the Sechelt Indian Residential School and attends the white school daily from there.

This enables her home study periods and work preparation to be supervised by the Principal of the Residential School.

Your letter to Major Mackay of 16th October, 1947 specified that her name should be retained on the Quarterly Return of the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

Theresa is making very good progress and gets along very well with the white pupils and was recently elected to office in the school girls organisation which gives us much satisfaction, in view of the attitude of many white parents towards attendance of Indians in public schools.

Regarding Norman Joseph, authority was given for a tuition grant in addition to the regular per capita allowance in order that Norman could attend the Sechelt Superior School whilst boarding at the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

He is over 16 years of age and is taking the high school course.

He also is doing well, being very good at sports as well

P.T.O.
as studies, and popular with the white pupils.

It was considered inadvisable to have this boy take high school in a North Vancouver school and live at home, as there is a bad gang influence there and his evenings and week-ends might have been devoted to other activities than study.

Yours truly,

(H. E. Taylor),
Indian Agent.

March 30, 1949.

W. S. Arneil, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Vancouver, B.C.

I enclose application form in duplicate for tuition grant for Joyce Bernadette Moody, No. 159 of the Squamish Indian Band, who is in attendance at St. Ann's Academy in Victoria, B.C.

When this girl left the Songhees Indian Day School, which she attended for seven years, the Reverend Father Bradley spoke highly in favour of admitting her into high school. I thereupon wrote to the Reverend Principal of St. Ann's Academy asking if they would accept this girl and what tuition fees would be. In the absence of any reply to my letter, the matter was not proceeded with.

I now find, however, that Joyce Moody has been in attendance at St. Ann's Academy from September 1947 to date, and that she is now in Grade 9 and making good progress. She has ambitions to graduate and to train as a nurse. The report on her progress would seem to justify recommending the continuance of her studies. The fees are $60.00 per year, and I would recommend that they be approved and made retroactive to September 1947.

The mother of this girl has been separated for many years from her husband, who resides on the reserve at Squamish. She is unable to provide for her daughter's education, and so far the Academy has received no fees.

(H. E. Taylor)
Indian Superintendent.

Re: Tuition Grant, Joyce Moody

Attached is an application for a tuition grant to enable the above mentioned pupil to continue her high school training at the St. Ann's Academy in Victoria, along with a letter in support of this application from Mr. Superintendent Taylor.

It will be noted that this girl has been attending St. Ann's Academy since September 1947 and that she is now in Grade 9. Although Mr. Taylor originally recommended payment of tuition fees as from the time of her admission, it is felt that in view of the fact that the Academy did not inform Mr. Taylor of her attendance in spite of his request for information, that the Department should pay for the current year only. This office has requested Mr. Taylor to endeavor to secure from the principal prompt advice as to the admission of Indian pupils from his Agency.

It is recommended that the attached voucher covering the period from September to December be paid and that the Department authorize an expenditure of $33.00 to cover tuition fees for the remaining six months of the current year.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
26th April, 1949.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

We have your letter of the 12th instant regarding tuition grants for Joyce Moody to enable her to continue her high school training for the current academic year.

In view of your recommendation we are paying Voucher 447 and we will allow an additional amount of $35.00 to cover tuition fees for the last six months of the current year. The marks she obtains on her June examinations should be submitted for our consideration if she intends to continue during the year 1949-50.

It is felt that the Principal of St. Ann's Academy in Victoria should be definitely informed that in future the Department will not be prepared to pay tuition grants for any Indian children attending that school unless their admission has previously been approved. In fairness to all parties concerned, if any educational institution expects a grant from the Department for the admission of an Indian child, our approval must be obtained before the child enters on a course.

Tuition Grants - Vancouver Agency
Reference your 15-11-1 (167) of July 15

As these students will be attending high school for the first time, it will be necessary to submit a tuition grant form for each applicant. It is presumed that these students will be living at the Sechelt Residential School and attending the Sechelt High School. If so, the applications are approved on the understanding that $75.00 per year tuition fees will be the only payments required other than the amounts allowed the residential school for extra clothing, etc.

A requisition should be forwarded at once for the high school books required by these students.

The Department is prepared to continue the tuition grant previously allowed Teresa Jeffries if she has been promoted to a higher grade.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

FUEL FOR SCHOOL
Rev. George Johnston was appointed teacher at the Kincolith Indian Day School as from October 1st this year. He lives in the Mission House at Kincolith. It is recommended that he be allowed fuel for his house whilst employed by the Department as teacher. In previous years the fuel requirements at Kincolith have been three tons of coal and three cords of wood. This is entirely inadequate if the teacher's house is included in fuel requirements. This winter has been exceptionally cold and severe. In conversation with Bishop Gibson he informs me that the teacher was allowed up to $100.00 worth of fuel per year for his residence but I cannot find any record of this on file.

It is recommended that an additional amount of 8 tons of egg coal and 4 cords of wood be provided for the Kincolith School and teacherage. It should be said that Mr. Johnston gives 5 days service a week full time to the Department's business and he should be entitled to the same consideration regarding fuel requirements as teachers in other village schools.

Coal can be purchased at Philpott, Evitt & Company Ltd., Prince Rupert, at a cost of $14.70 per ton plus $6.25 per ton freight and sacks. A purchase order is requested.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian-Agent.
AIRMAIL

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letter of December 16th in connection with the proposed supply of fuel for the Reverend George Johnston, teacher at the Kincolith Indian Day School for use in the Mission House. The quantities of fuel recommended by the Agent would cost in the neighborhood of $200.00 and as Mr. Johnston is being allowed salary at the rate of $125.00 per teaching month this would make his total remuneration equivalent to $145.00 per month. This amount is in excess of what we are paying most certificated teachers.

Apparently an allowance up to $100.00 worth of fuel for the year was previously made to the teacher at this school and I would suggest that this be continued.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

AIR MAIL

W. S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B. C., Box 70, Vancouver.

Re your 12-11-1 of April 14th, 1948, having reference to fuel needs at the Sunnyside seasonal Day School, will you please delete the item of $127.25 from our requisition for funds for this Agency for heating Day Schools. There is nothing on file in writing from the B. C. Packers Ltd. to the effect that they will supply fuel though correspondence from Mr. Gillett, Agent, would indicate that some verbal arrangement had been reached on this point. Whilst at Sunnyside earlier this year, I gathered that there was an intention to charge for fuel for the School but as the informant was a minor employee, it is possible he was misinformed. As soon as the Manager and Accountant arrive at Sunnyside, I shall have a conference with them and endeavor to get a written agreement. In the meantime, I would appreciate the forwarding of our request for an accountable advance for other Schools.

F. Earl Anfield.
Indian Agent.
P.O. Box 187.

AIR MAIL

W. S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B. C., Box 70, Vancouver.

Prince Rupert, B. C.
April 9th, 1948.

Attached please find list of fuel requirements for the schools of this Agency for the fiscal year 1948-49. Authority is requested to purchase the coal at the best available figure from local sources, also fuel oil requirements. An accountable advance of $1683.15 is requested, if possible by airmail, to meet costs of cutting wood fuel and for delivery charges by Indian gas boats on other fuel needs.

The fuel requirements of the Agency are higher than last year due to the fact that the Kitselas School has been re-opened on a 10 months basis and also with fuel requirements for Sunnyside School are included this year. It should be said, however, that so far the B. C. Packers have provided the fuel requirements for this school but I have reason to believe that they intend billing us for them in the future.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Enclosed herewith is Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letters of April 9th and April 26th and summary of fuel required for schools in his Agency for the current fiscal year.

It will be noted that the item of $127.25 for fuel needs of the Summside Indian Day School has been deleted pending a conference between the Agent and B.C. Packers Limited regarding the provision of fuel for this school.

It is recommended that Mr. Anfield be authorized to purchase fuel as requested and that an accountable advance of $1647.15 to cover cost of cutting wood fuel and for delivery charges be forwarded to the Agent by air mail if possible.

W. B. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

On a recent visit to Sunnyside Cannery, I discussed this matter with the Manager and the Accountant in some detail. Their statements co-incide in general with those of Mr. Gillett that the arrangements at the time this school was opened was of a purely temporary nature. The B. C. Packers agree that they will supply a furnished house for the teacher and a nurse at Sunnyside Cannery but they do not feel obligated to supply fuel either for this teacherage-nursing post or for the school.

Up to last fall, the teacher lived in a little one-room shack next to the school but on the appointment of Miss Freeman to the position of teacher arrangements were made with the B. C. Packers to give her a furnished house gratis. Under the circumstances, it is recommended that the voucher as submitted be paid and that a sum of $268.00 be authorized for the purchase of the following fuel requirements for the balance of the present fiscal year:

\[
\begin{align*}
4 \text{ tons of coal} & @ \$18.25 = \$73.00 \\
1000 \text{ gals. oil} & @ 19.5 = \$195.00
\end{align*}
\]
It should be said that the cannery really has nothing to gain by having a school at Sunnyside except for the three months of April, May and June when their Indian crews come in for cannery work. During these months, the children of these families can receive education. What is actually happening is that an ever increasing number of our Native people are leaving their Reserves and living at canneries such as Sunnyside and Port Edward where they are establishing more or less permanent domiciles. At Sunnyside Cannery some of the men whose families attend school are in the employ of the cannery for repair work and cannery boat building projects during the winter. At Port Edward most of the parents of the children attending school are employees of this plant which is rapidly reaching a twelve-months operational basis.

Whilst not immediately pertinent to this fuel problem at Sunnyside, this situation should be watched very closely as in my opinion the day is coming when the Department could quite justifiably claim that the education of these children is the responsibility of the Province. These large fishing corporations such as Nelson Bros. and B.C. Packers are among the heaviest taxpayers in the Prince Rupert School district and it would seem to me that within two or three years we could justifiably claim that the children of their Native employees should not be a charge on the Indian Affairs Branch for purposes of education.

This entire situation should be watched with particular care at Port Edward where the Cellanese Corporation of America are establishing a huge plant and where it is quite likely a considerable number of Indian families will locate as employees in the raw products operation of this concern.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Further to my letter of April 29th regarding school fuel requirements, Skeena River Agency and in particular my reference to the fuel needs of the Sunnyside Indian Day School, I am enclosing Superintendent Anfield's letter of June 10th and enclosures referred to therein. While I have noted Mr. Anfield's comments regarding provincial responsibility in the matter of provision of education for Indian children at the Sunnyside and other canneries I doubt whether this is an appropriate time to raise the question.

I would recommend that the attached voucher No. 560 be passed for payment and that the Department approve an expenditure of $285.00 for provision of the fuel needs of the school for the present fiscal year.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Fuel Requirements - Skeena River Agency

Attached for your information is a letter dated March 29th received from Superintendent Anfield, together with a table showing fuel requirements for the schools in his Agency for the fiscal year 1949-50.

In forwarding this letter, Indian Commissioner Arnell writes as follows:

"I would recommend that an accountable advance of $2,174.50 be forwarded to Mr. Anfield for the purchase of wood fuel and hauling services of Indians."

This is the usual procedure with reference to the purchase of wood from Indians, and we will forward the accountable advance as requested. Mr. Arnell writes regarding the coal as follows:

"If possible, Mr. Anfield should be authorized to incur expenditures to a total of $3,386.71 for the local purchase of coal and oil, it being understood that purchasing regulations will be complied with."

Please let me know what action should be taken with reference to the latter recommendation.

Philip Phelan,

Ottawa, 3 January 1947.

Mr. F.E. Anfield, Indian Agent,
PRINCE RUPERT, B.C.

In your report for the quarter ended Sept. 20, you wrote in part as follows:- "Some nine pupils are taking advanced studies in the Prince Rupert City High School". At the present time we are engaged in checking the grants that we have authorized for higher education for the current academic year and we can only locate the names of six children who are attending Prince Rupert High School namely, Oscar Mercer, L. Garner, George Kelly, Lawrence Helin, Percy Adams, and Virginia Clark. Bertram McKay is attending Langley High School. The names just mentioned number seven.

Please let me know if there are any other Indian children in your Agency attending High school and if so give their names, ages, grades, and schools in which they are enrolled. If there are more than the seven mentioned above it is presumed that their parents are paying the cost of their education.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Reference your 103-168 (W.T. 1) of January 3rd, the following pupils are attending High School in Prince Rupert: Laurence Garner, George Kelly, Oscar Mercer, Percy Adams, Lawrence Helin and Virginia Clark. These are all on a grant earning basis and are all from this Agency.

In addition to these, Ronald Brown of Massett Agency is in receipt of a grant being administered by this office. In addition to these 7 children, Walter Harris of Babine Agency and Donald York of Massett Agency are attending the local High School and doing particularly well. I am not aware if grants are being paid for these two or not.

My purpose in stating "some nine pupils" in my September report was that I visit these schools every month in an effort to keep tab on the progress of these young people all of whom in High School appear to have behaved themselves in an orderly manner and are making good progress in their studies.

In addition to these children attending the Prince Rupert schools Bertram McKay is attending the Langley High School. As far as is known, no other children of the Agency are attending High School.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
February 14, 1947

F. E. Anfield, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C.

Your voucher No. 136 covering tuition fees for Indian pupils attending white schools, Prince Rupert District, is being forwarded to the Department and recommended for payment.

I would point out however that insofar as this office is aware departmental authorization for the attendance of these pupils at white schools has not been secured. I would refer you to my circular letter, O-11-1 of August 14, 1946 and particularly the penultimate paragraph which states that an Agent may give temporary authorization for such attendance but that the authority of the Department is to be secured as soon as possible.

Please let me have a report with respect to the pupils listed in the accounts covered by your voucher above referred to giving in each case details with respect to the circumstances which necessitate the pupil's attendance at a white school when there is an Indian Day School in operation on his Reserve.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Fees, elementary school pupils, Prince Rupert.

Missis Coleman, Darry and Anfield are a bit concerned about this question. Mr. Coleman takes the view that, where the parents are domiciled in the school district, there is no liability for special fees. Mr. Anfield is more inclined to distribute funds for any purpose which will accelerate the assimilation of Indians. He was, perhaps, a little enthusiastic in promising the Board that he would recommend payment.

I think we should get a legal opinion regarding liability. We should also get a copy of the B.C. Manual of School Law.

One factor deserves consideration. The Board is not—repeat not—charging us the per capita cost of educating these pupils. If they got tough and charged us the actual cost for high school pupils we should have to pay that.

I had useful discussions with Coleman and Darry who would like to continue the talks here on board. I'm getting some inside stuff from people who live at various points in the Yukon. Visits to Mayo, Burwash Landing, Carmacks, appear indicated.

Circular to All Indian Agents:

A procedure has now been established by the Department in connection with the attendance of Indian children at Elementary White schools.

Although under no circumstances should an Indian child be delayed from attending a Provincial school pending departmental authorization Agents should in August or early September submit a report to the Department through this office on Indian children for whom the Department will be required to pay tuition fees.

In the event that an Agent only learns in late August or after the start of the school term that an Indian child will have no alternative other than to attend a white school he may at once give temporary authorization for this attendance, departmental authorization to be secured as soon as possible. Cases such as this should be the exception rather than the rule, however, and it should be the normal procedure for Agents to anticipate such attendance and obtain authorization beforehand.

Cases already referred to this office covering attendance during the 1946-47 Academic year are being submitted to the Department.

D. M. MacKay,

Also his letter of the same date respecting similar payment of fees totalling $485.00 for children of the Queen Charlotte Agency. It will be noted that the parents of practically all the children have apparently been gainfully employed and resident in Prince Rupert for some time.

It will be observed that Mr. Anfield draws a distinction between the 18 months clause in respect to relief and medical services for Indians on the grounds that the education of Indians is obligatory on the Dominion Government under the provisions of the British North America Act, but reference to Mr. Hoey's letter of May 16th, 1944, file 600401, expresses the opinion that it is the duty of the municipalities etc. in which Indians are resident to provide for their welfare, mentioning "education" in subsection (1) of the second paragraph, which would indicate that the Department feels that such municipal responsibility included this and all such services in consideration of the fact that an Indian renting premises in a town or municipality was an indirect tax payer. There are cases where Indians own such property.

Examination of Agent Anfield's premises do not justify his conclusion. Closed schools at Kincolith and Greenville, overcrowding at Kitkatla and Aiyansh, unsatisfactory teachers at Port Simpson, do not necessarily or even probably account for the parents of the children living at Prince Rupert. He further mentions that Kitkatla has only one untrained teacher. His letter of Sept. 4, 1946 states that this teacher, Mrs. Grace Vickers, "has a successful career as a teacher and there is no question but that the Department would approve her appointment,"
(your file 168-18-1 (WT1). He considers we become liable for the fees when economic needs or parental ambition leads to the Indians settlement in areas where white schools are in operation.

He claims authority for assuring the School Board that he would support their application in this office's circular of August 14, 1946 asking Indian Agents to advise this office as soon as possible what children would be attending white schools at the expense of the Department. About six weeks previously our circular of June 27th, 1946 on the same subject advised very specifically that the Department should not be called upon to pay these fees for children residing in organized municipalities in premises assessed for taxes. There was nothing in the subsequent directive to entitle him to assume that this principle had been abandoned.

Mr. Anfield's reference to Section 63 of the "School Act" of B.C., it is believed, should read Section 63 (3) (b). I cannot agree with his interpretation of the section. This section dealing with the power of Municipal Council to fix minimum property tax, and to impose other taxes for school purposes is as follows:

"To direct, in respect of any year, that where neither of the parents of any child or children attending public school in the municipal school district is taxed for school purposes in respect of property within the district, the parents or the surviving parent of the child or children shall pay a tax for school purposes in the district; and to fix the amount thereof which shall be payable monthly or otherwise as the Council may direct: Provided that the amount so fixed shall not be less than the amount of the minimum tax imposed and payable under clause (a) of this subsection, and shall not be greater than that amount by more than fifty per centum:"

Of interest in this connection is the interpretation in the Act of "Indian" as follows:

"Indian" means any person who is either a full-blooded Indian, or any person with Indian blood in him who is living the Indian life on an Indian reserve."

If Mr. Anfield's argument is considered valid
the Department must be prepared to meet numerous demands for similar cases in other Agencies in this Province as there are many Indians who have not lived on the Reserves or followed the Indian mode of life for many years, in some cases having purchased lands outside the Reserves for the sole purpose of co-education of their children with whites in their schools. It is of interest in this connection to note that the franchise in British Columbia has recently been extended to such Indians.

Where the parents are already contributing directly or indirectly by the occupation of taxable premises there is no justification for further payment from public funds, as such Indian taxpayers are entitled to the rights and privileges of any other taxpayers. This is not intended to exclude from assistance those children resident on a reserve for whom we cannot provide ordinary or advanced education and are attending white schools with department assistance.

It appears that a restatement of Departmental policy is necessary and it would be appreciated if you would secure a ruling from the department on the subject.

However, since Mr. Anfield has apparently given some assurance to the Prince Rupert School Board that the fees will be paid by the Department it is recommended that their payment be authorized with the stipulation that this does not set a precedent for future applications.

R.F. Davey,
District Inspector of Indian Schools.

When these and other children applied for admission to these schools last Fall, I was asked for a definite yes or no by the School Board as to whether or not their fees would be paid by the Department. In view of (a) closed schools at Kincolith and Greenville (b) overcrowded conditions at Kitkatla and Aiyansh (c) an unsatisfactory teaching staff at Port Simpson (d) the fact that parents of these children were earning their livelihood in Prince Rupert instead of being without employment on the reserves (e) the genuine desire of the parents to secure proper educational facilities for their children, and (f) your Circular O-11-1 of August 14th, 1946 authorizing temporary admission of applicants, I gave the School Board an assurance that I would endorse the admissions and recommend payment of the accounts presented. Section 63B, and the responsibility of the Department to provide educational facilities for Indians under the B.N. Act. It is fully agreed that where adequate school facilities are provided, Indian children should attend the village day schools. I do contend, however, that the Department's responsibility does not cease when economic needs and or parents ambitions for better educational facilities compel the removal of families to areas where white schools are available.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

Re your 215-11-6996 of April 9th dealing with Queen Charlotte Island children attending Prince Rupert City Schools, this matter has been discussed with Mr. J.A. Findlay, Acting Agent at Massett, and we agree on the following presentation to the Department:

1. Last fall I was asked by the School Board as to the intention or otherwise of the Department to pay School accounts for native pupils admitted to city schools. My reply was an affirmative one as to recommendation for payment.

2. The Day Schools at Massett were closed for lack of teachers and several families moved over to Prince Rupert to enable them to work and have their children attend school. I admitted them to the city schools and told the school board I would recommend payment of accounts by the Department.

3. With regard to the statement that parents were working at Port Edward Cannery, the Collinsons, Whites and Parnells were working at Seal Cove Cannery and not Port Edward as stated by Mr. Indian Agent Phillips. They may have gone out to Port Edward for a few weeks only at the height of the herring season, when that plant was desperately short of help. I checked with Millards at Seal Cove and found that these people were on the clam canning operation.

4. We are not aware that the 18 months clause applicable in medical matters can be applied to education. Our understanding is that Indian education is the direct responsibility of the Department and that if for any reason, school facilities are not adequate or available on the reserves, the Department is obligated to assist in securing or paying for same elsewhere.
5. Whilst it is admitted that the School Board has no right to refuse admission of these school pupils. I am convinced that the Department is legally bound to pay fees, they standing in loco-parentis to these Crown wards. When not directly taxable for property in Prince Rupert, I believe these fees are due and payable under Section 63 B of the School Act.

6. In general, attendance of most of these Indian children in the city schools has been regular and their progress very satisfactory. There has been no noticeable discrimination and a tribute is paid to the interest and attention given them by the teachers and principals concerned.

The grants requested are recommended in all cases.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,

We have your letter of the 12th instant enclosing letter of April 30th from Indian Agent Anfield and a report from Inspector Davey in connection with payment of school fees for Indian children enrolled in the elementary grades at the Prince Rupert public school.

On reviewing our files we find that you submitted voucher 664 covering the tuition fees for these pupils for the month of September, 1946 and payment was made. We also received your voucher 136 dated February 10th, 1947, for the same pupils for the months of October, November and December, 1946. Both the above vouchers were paid as we overlooked the fact that the pupils were in the elementary grades, and no specific authority had been given to pay tuition fees for them.

As you are aware, our policy in the past has been as follows:

1. The Department will pay tuition fees for Indian children in public white schools provided they reside on the reserve and there are no educational facilities available on their home reserve.

2. We have never assumed responsibility for education of Indian children in elementary grades when the parents reside in a municipality and are either house owners or tenants. We have
always considered that in such cases they are entitled to the same consideration as any other resident of the municipality.

Mr. Anfield had no authority to promise the Prince Rupert Public School Board that we would pay tuition fees of any children who have been enrolled in the elementary grades. Such procedure would be contrary to our policy outlined above and would involve us all over Canada with other school boards.

However, it is evident from the correspondence that he promised the Prince Rupert Board and unfortunately we paid the two vouchers mentioned above without checking on them. Under these circumstances, it has been decided to pay the fees for the current academic year only, but we will not be responsible for such fees after the end of June, 1947.

I have to refer to the application for a grant of $500.00 to enable Leonard D. Leighton of the Metlakatla Band to attend Normal School during the 1947-48 academic year, and letters in support of this application from Mr. Indian Agent Anfield and the applicant.

Mr. Leighton has completed his Junior Matriculation and in April of this year received a degree of L.Th. from the Anglican Theological College, Vancouver, B.C., after four years of training at that institution. The church authorities apparently expected that he would be ordained following his graduation and gave him assistance towards his training in theology. It now appears that he does not intend to enter the ministry.

In view of the lack of stability shown in the abandoning of his plan to enter the ministry after four years' training and without giving it any definite trial, it is felt that the Department would hesitate to approve the amount of $500.00. An alternative might be to employ Mr. Leighton for a year as teacher in one of the Indian Day Schools. This should enable him to save something and make a larger contribution towards his training. He has had several weeks' teaching at the St. Cyprian Indian Residential school at Brocket, Alberta. Inspector Davey believes he would be suitable for one of the schools either in the Skeena or Queen Charlotte Agencies where we are having difficulty in securing teachers. Mr. Leighton's home is in this area and such a position would be attractive to him.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Attached please find application and medical report on Gloria Morven, applicant for a grant of $375.00 to enable her to continue her High School education in Prince Rupert. We shall be able to place her at the Salvation Army Hostel where she will be well cared for. Her father is dead and her mother has made a real effort to put up her share of the cost. In connection with these girls I would quote from a report of Rev. S.J. Wickens of Alert Bay Indian Residential School, who comments on their remaining in a boarding school as follows:

"I am strongly of the opinion, however, that they should not return to this School to continue their studies, even though the Superior School in the village will be teaching Grade 9 and 10 work. I think it is generally believed that it is to the advantage of such young people that they should meet the challenge of High School life separate from the restraining influence to which necessarily our younger children are subject. Obviously we have to expect them to observe the same discipline and regimentation to which the whole School has to adhere. If they are to learn poise and self-discipline, they should certainly be free from the restraint we have to impose on juveniles.

I therefore urge these young people should be given an opportunity to attend High School in Prince Rupert, and I trust you may be able to make early arrangements with their parents and the Department that they may continue their studies which they have shown through their past industry they deserve to do. I have spoken to these pupils and they fully understand the point of view I am expressing to you. I trust you will do your very best to give them a chance to go on to further studies."
I agree with the Rev. Principal and as I believe Gloria wishes to train as a nurse, endorse her application and if approved request a grant payable to Indian Agency Trust Account.

March 19th, 1948.

W. S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B. C., Box 70,
Vancouver.

Re Credit Voucher No. 302. An explanation is necessary
as to why these funds were unspent. Mary Johnson started
school very happily in September 1947 and seemed to be making
good progress in her studies. She suddenly became very un-
happy and inspite of every effort by this office and also
her own Agent, Mr. Boys, she left Prince Rupert and went back
to her mother, later obtaining employment in the Smithers
Hospital.

She was a very large girl for her age and in addition
was seriously retarded as to Grade. It is my opinion from
discussion with the Principal and teachers involved that she
developed a violent inferiority complex. Most of the pupils
in her class would be about half her size. I held the funds
hoping that she might change her mind after Christmas.

Mary turned in all her text books and school supplies
purchased and these have been placed in our school stock cup-
board and are available for other pupils in future. There
will be no loss from this purchase. A copy of this letter
is being forwarded to Mr. Boys for his information.

F. Earl Anfield.
Indian Agent.

cc. J. V. Boys, Esq.

Re: Port Essington School.

On April 8th I visited the Port Essington Provincial School in the company of Mr. Indian Agent Anfield and Inspector E. Hyndman of the Provincial Department of Education.

There were 38 pupils on the roll, all of whom were of Indian or mixed origin. Of this number, there were 18 of Indian status, one of whom was absent due to illness.

There was a very happy atmosphere in the classroom and the pupils appeared to be making excellent progress. Last year separate schools were in operation at this point and I was fortunate in being able to compare attendance records for this year with that of last and previous years. The improvement in this respect was most striking. In the corresponding week last year, the number of Indian pupils attending our school was 7 and on going back through the register to the 1944-45 academic year, I noted that for no quarter did the average attendance of our pupils reach 14 although as many as 22 had been enrolled. In the present year, the average attendance has been well over 90%.

The attendance has so far exceeded our expectations and the Provincial authorities find it necessary to operate another room next year.

R. F. Davey
District Inspector of Indian Schools.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I am enclosing for your information a copy of District School Inspector Davey's letter dated April 16th in connection with the attendance of Indian children at the Port Essington Provincial School. This arrangement for the provision of educational facilities for these children appears to be very satisfactory.

RE: Leonard LEIGHTON - Kispiox Indian Day School

The above-named who has been teaching at Kispiox Indian Day School (Primary grades) since early in the current academic year has informed me that he wishes to attend Normal School next year but that he is unable to finance the whole cost of the course.

Leighton is an Indian of the Metlakatla Band in the Skeena River agency and has been rendering excellent service at Kispiox. He states that he will be in a position to put up a minimum of $300.00 towards his expenses, the full amount of which he does not know but he asks if the Department by means of a grant or even a loan would make available the balance required. I heartily recommend this application. I do not know exactly how much extra would be required to put Mr. Leighton through the Normal School but perhaps Mr. School Inspector Davey could supply this information.

Vancouver, B.C.

To: The Indian Commissioner for B.C.
From: The District School Inspector.

Re: Application for tuition grant
Leonard D. Leighton

I refer to the letter of Mr. Indian Agent Anfield dated May 10th concerning the above. It will be noted that Mr. Leighton has done satisfactory work at the Kispiox School and that he is prepared to contribute $300.00 towards the cost of his course. It is also to be noted that at the present time Mr. Leighton is receiving a salary of only $1000.00 per year and consequently his contribution represents a definite effort on his part.

The following is a statement of the fixed charges in connection with this course:

| Fees | $57.00 |
|------|--------|
| Board | 450.00 |
| Books | 25.00 |

$532.00

You will note that I have included $450.00 for board. This figure is based upon the amount which we have had to pay in at least one case to accommodate an Indian pupil attending high school in Vancouver and I anticipate that Mr. Leighton will be fortunate if he secures board and lodging for as low as that amount.

Nothing has been included for incidental expenses such as laundry, transportation either to Vancouver and return or for car fare while attending the Normal School. Mr. Leighton will only be able to keep under a figure of $700.00 by exercising extreme care. I would recommend a grant of $400.00 to Mr. Leighton.

R.F. Davey,
Dist. School Inspector.

Ottawa, Ont.

APPRENTICESHIP ACT

Employment of Minors Prohibited except under Contract or written Permit

Under the provisions of the Apprenticeship Act, the employment of minors in any trade or occupation designated is prohibited, except under Contract of Apprenticeship in conformity with the regulations, or under written Permit covering probationary employment preliminary to apprenticeship. A designated trade is any trade or calling brought under the provisions of the Apprenticeship Act.

Apprenticeship Age.

Apprenticeship is open to any person over the age of fifteen years.

Apprenticeship Contracts

No Apprenticeship Contract in a designated trade shall have any force or effect until it has been approved by the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee and registered by the Director of Apprenticeship. The Committee must be satisfied that proper training facilities are available with reasonable continuity of employment.

Termination of an Apprenticeship Contract.

Subject to the approval of the Minister of Labour, a Contract of Apprenticeship may be terminated by mutual agreement of all parties thereto, or may be cancelled by the Director, if he is shown good cause by either the Employer, the Apprentice, or the Guardian.

Penalties.

The Act provides penalties ranging from $10.00 to $100.00 on summary conviction for violation of any of its provisions.

Note.

The above is a summary of the essential features of the Act but in no way affects any provisions of the Act itself or its interpretation. CHAPTER 12.

An Act respecting the Training of Apprentices.

[Consolidated for convenience only, August 7th, 1944.]

HIS MAJESTY, by and with the advice and consent of the Legislative Assembly of the Province of British Columbia, enacts as follows:

1. This Act may be cited as the "Apprenticeship Act."

2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires:
   "Apprentice" means a person at least fifteen years of age who enters into a contract of service in accordance with this Act, whereby he is to receive from or through his employer instruction in any designated trade;
   "Designated trade" means any trade designated in Schedule A, including any trade added to Schedule A under the provisions of section 4;
   "Director" means the Director of Apprenticeship appointed under this Act;
   "Employer," in respect of an apprentice, means the person to whom the apprentice is under contract of service, and who is responsible for the instruction of the apprentice in any designated trade;
   "Minister" means the Minister of Labour;
   "Trade" includes industry, trade, craft, or business and any branch of any industry, trade, craft, or business.

3. (1.) The provisions of this Act shall apply only in respect of apprenticeship in the trades designated in Schedule A, or hereafter added to Schedule A under the provisions of section 4.
   (2.) Subject to section 10 of this Act, sections 8 to 29 of the "Infants Act" shall not apply in respect of the apprenticing of minors in any designated trade.
APPRENTICESHIP.

(3.) Notwithstanding any provision of the "Municipal Act" or the "Village Municipalities Act," any municipality to which either of those Acts applies may as an employer enter into any contract of apprenticeship pursuant to the provisions of this Act. 1937, c. 2, s. 2.

4. (1.) Upon the receipt of a petition signed by a representative number of employers in any trade to the satisfaction of the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee asking to have that trade added to Schedule A, or of an agreement in writing entered into between a representative association of employers in any trade and a representative group or union of employees in that trade to the satisfaction of the Minister for the addition of that trade to Schedule A, the Minister shall direct the Director to inquire into the matter; and the Director shall thereupon make such investigation as may be considered necessary to determine whether or not that trade should be added to Schedule A. The Minister may at his own motion direct an inquiry by the Director in respect of any trade for the purpose of this section.

(2.) The Lieutenant-Governor in Council, upon the recommendation of the Minister, may from time to time add to Schedule A such other trades as may be considered expedient, and may from time to time reclassify or withdraw from Schedule A any trade, whether originally in that Schedule or subsequently added thereto by the Lieutenant-Governor in Council. 1940, c. 1, s. 2.

5. (1.) The Lieutenant-Governor in Council may appoint a Provincial Apprenticeship Committee to advise the Minister on all matters connected with the general conditions governing apprenticeship.

(2.) The Lieutenant-Governor in Council may appoint a Director of Apprenticeship for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this Act, and may also appoint such other officers and clerks for that purpose as may be considered necessary or expedient.

(3.) The Director, officers, and clerks shall be under the direction and control of the Minister who shall be charged with the administration of this Act.

6. Subject to the regulations, it shall be the duty of the Director—

(a.) To keep a register of every contract of apprenticeship entered into by an apprentice in accordance with the provisions of this Act;

(b.) To make such examination and inquiry as may be necessary to ascertain whether the provisions of this Act are being complied with by both employer and apprentice;

(c.) To arouse and promote interest in the adoption of apprenticeship in trades;

(d.) To assist in establishing a permanent system of training of apprentices in any trade;

(e.) To provide such information as may be required by apprenticeship committees;

(f.) To collaborate with educational authorities in the training of apprentices;

(g.) To submit a report annually to the Minister;

(h.) Generally to perform such other duties and exercise such powers as may be prescribed by the Minister for carrying out the provisions of this Act.

7. No person shall enter into any contract of apprenticeship in a designated trade except in accordance with the provisions of this Act.

8. (1.) Subject to sections 10 and 11, a minor under the age of fifteen years shall not be employed in a designated trade; and a minor of the age of fifteen years or over shall not be employed in a designated trade except under the following conditions. Where the employment is preliminary to entering into a contract of apprenticeship in accordance with this Act, and where he has obtained from the Director a written permit in the form prescribed by the Minister, a minor of the age of fifteen years or over may be employed in a designated trade for a period or periods which shall not, unless an extension is granted by the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee, exceed a total of three months. The Provincial Apprenticeship Committee may grant an extension, in which case the Director shall issue a permit extending the period of employment for such additional time as the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee thinks proper; and the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee may grant an extension as often as it thinks proper so to do. Where a minor of the age of fifteen years or over has entered into a contract of apprenticeship in accordance with this Act he may be employed in a designated trade during the term of apprenticeship, and when he has completed the term of apprenticeship he may be employed in the trade in which he has served his apprenticeship.

(2.) Subsection (1) shall not apply to a minor who has prior to the ninth day of September, 1935, completed the period of apprenticeship elsewhere in the designated trade, or to a minor employed only as a common labourer.

(3.) Where, in the opinion of the Minister, it is expedient for a minor to be employed without entering into a contract of apprenticeship at specialized or repetitive work within a designated trade in or incidental to the production or manufacture of...
war supplies, the Minister may, by exemption in writing, suspend the necessity of entering into a contract of apprenticeship for such time as the minor is engaged at such work. The Minister may prescribe the terms, conditions, and extent of the exemption, and any infraction thereof shall render the exemption null and void. 1938, c. 1, s. 2; 1940, c. 1, s. 3; 1941-42, c. 4, s. 3.

9. (1.) Every contract of apprenticeship shall be in the form set out in Schedule B, except that the Minister may, upon the recommendation of the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee, authorize the variation of the form.

(2.) The contract shall not be of any force or effect until it has been approved by the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee and by the Director by writing endorsed thereon, and has been registered by the Director in the manner prescribed by the regulations.

(3.) Subject to section 11, a contract of apprenticeship under this Act shall not be entered into for a period of less than two years, except with the permission of the Minister on the recommendation of the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee. 1940, c. 1, s. 4.

10. (1.) Where a minor has been employed under a contract of apprenticeship in any designated trade prior to the ninth day of September, 1935, and the contract was subsisting at that date, and the employer of the minor filed the contract within three months after that date for registration in the office of the Director, the contract and the apprenticeship thereunder, subject to the approval of the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee, shall in all other respects be regarded as if this Act had not been passed.

(2.) Where a minor has been employed under a contract of apprenticeship in any trade prior to the date on which that trade is added to Schedule A under the provisions of section 4, and the contract is subsisting at that date, the employer of the minor shall file the contract within three months after that date for registration in the office of the Director, but the contract and the apprenticeship thereunder, subject to the approval of the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee, shall in all other respects be regarded as if this Act had not been passed.

11. (1.) Where a minor has been employed in a designated trade prior to the ninth day of September, 1935, but not under a contract of apprenticeship, and the employment was continuing at that date, the provisions of this Act shall in relation to any unexpired period of his employment apply as from the expiration of three months after that date; and the period during which the minor was so employed may, with the approval of the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee, be allowed as part of the time required to complete the full period of his subsequent apprenticeship.

(2.) Where a minor has been employed in a designated trade prior to the date on which that trade is added to Schedule A under the provisions of section 4, but not under a contract of apprenticeship, and the employment is continuing at that date, the provisions of this Act shall in relation to any unexpired period of his employment apply as from the expiration of three months after that date; and the period during which the minor was so employed may, with the approval of the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee, be allowed as part of the time required to complete the full period of his subsequent apprenticeship.

12. Every contract of apprenticeship shall be signed:

(a.) By the employer to whom the minor is to be apprenticed or by the employer or his duly authorized representative;

(b.) By the person to be apprenticed; and

(c.) In case the person to be apprenticed is a minor, by the sole guardian of the minor under the "Equal Guardianship of Infants Act," and, in the case of there being joint guardians, by any one of them. 1940, c. 1, s. 5.

13. (1.) The Director may refuse to register any contract of apprenticeship which in his opinion is not for the benefit of the apprentice.

(2.) Where the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee approves a contract of apprenticeship, but the Director refuses to register the same, the matter in dispute shall be referred to the Minister, whose decision shall be final.

14. Notwithstanding the provisions of any law or Statute to the contrary, every minor who enters into a contract of apprenticeship which is registered in accordance with the provisions of this Act shall be liable upon the same, and shall have the benefit thereof according to its terms, as if he had been of legal age; but the registration of a contract of apprenticeship shall not be regarded as a guarantee that the provisions of the contract are valid or that any provision thereof is not in conflict with the provisions of this Act.

15. Subject to the approval of the Minister, a contract of apprenticeship:

(a.) May be terminated by mutual agreement of all the parties thereto; or

(b.) May be cancelled by the Director, upon good cause being shown to his satisfaction by the employer or the apprentice or his guardian; and the fact of the termination or cancellation shall be endorsed by the Director upon the copy of the contract registered in his office.

16. Where the terms of a contract of apprenticeship cannot be fulfilled, the Director may arrange for the transfer of the apprentice to another employer; but such transfer shall not become effective until it has been approved by the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee and has been registered by the Director.

Regulations.

17. The Lieutenant-Governor in Council may make regulations:

(a.) To establish for any defined area an apprenticeship committee or committees to advise the Minister on all matters connected with the conditions governing apprenticeship in any designated trade within that area;

(b.) Prescribing the powers, duties and functions of apprenticeship committees relative to: The designation of any trade; the period or periods of apprenticeship; the qualifications upon which apprenticeship may commence in any designated trade; the standard of education for the apprentice; the nature and number of educational classes to be attended by the apprentice; the course of training to be given an apprentice in a designated trade; the issuance of a certificate to an apprentice who has completed his term of service; fixing the hours of labour and rates of wages for apprentices; and the recommending of such methods of assessment of employers as may be considered necessary to maintain a system of apprenticeship in any designated trade;

(c.) Specifying the number and qualifications of members of an apprenticeship committee, and fixing the period of appointment and the method of designating or appointing a chairman and other officers;

(d.) Governing the procedure of an apprenticeship committee at its meetings and the time and place of such meetings;

(e.) Providing for books, records, and forms to be used by an apprenticeship committee;

(f.) Prescribing the duties and obligations which shall be imposed upon and observed by an employer in respect of his apprentice;

(g.) Prescribing the duties and obligations which shall be imposed upon and observed by an apprentice in respect of his employer;

(h.) Prescribing the number and qualifications of the apprentices who may be employed or trained in any designated trade;

(i.) Establishing and carrying out a system of assessment for levying and collecting from all the employers in any designated trade such moneys as may be considered necessary from time to time to maintain a system of apprenticeship and instruction in that designated trade;

(j.) Generally such other matters as may be necessary for the proper carrying-out of the provisions of this Act.

18. The members of the Provincial Apprenticeship Committee and of every apprenticeship committee established under the regulations shall be paid such allowances as remuneration for their services and for the expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of their duties as may be fixed by the regulations, which allowances shall be payable out of such sums as may from time to time be appropriated by the Legislature for that purpose, or in the absence of a special appropriation shall be payable from the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

19. Every person who:

(a.) Enters into a contract of apprenticeship in respect of any designated trade except in accordance with the provisions of this Act; or

(b.) Except as expressly provided by this Act, employs any minor in a designated trade; or

(c.) Contravenes any of the provisions of this Act or any regulation made thereunder,—shall be liable, on summary conviction, to a fine of not less than ten dollars and not more than one hundred dollars.
