Re: Lawrence Garner, Port Simpson, B.C.

The above named lad, born April 1931, attended the Booth Memorial High School, this city for the past two years. He is ready to go into Grade XI, having earned 23 credits, with one subject, Metalwork incomplete; due to his having left school before the final exam in this subject. Lawrence is a very fine lad, of good character and undoubted intelligence. He is a fine physical specimen and has proved most adept at woodwork, mathematics and science. I had a long talk with his instructors about his future and they and the Principal strongly concur with Lawrence's own desire to be apprenticed as a journeyman boat builder, whilst continuing to take credits in his high school work by correspondence under the supervision of the local High School.

I have today had a long interview with Mr. Ted Ivay, Inspector of the Apprenticeship Division of the Provincial Government of B.C. and Mr. McLean of McLean's Shipyard of this city. The latter is willing to take the boy as an apprentice under the Act, particulars of which I am asking the Vancouver office of the Department to forward to you.

Lawrence is anxious to learn a trade, in preference to finishing his High School graduation course. His mother is a widow and cannot contribute much to his support as she has other children to raise. His father was a First World War overseas veteran who later died. Lawrence has discussed his future with me at some length. He would be nineteen when he completes High School Graduation and would still be without a trade. Under an apprenticeship he would learn and earn and if the Department could help him for the first year or so, he could be on his own and able
to help support his mother within 2 years, at the same time learning a worthwhile trade. There is a desperate shortage of journeymen boat builders and if the lad made good, he would have an assured livelihood and would be able to carry out his stated interest of moving his mother from the reserve to a home in Prince Rupert.

You will note that his wages under the apprenticeship contract will be approximately 27% of the journeymans wage of $1.27½ hour for an 8 hour day or maximum 40 hour week. This, if employment was constant, would give him an assured wage of $55.00 a month, less income tax, hospital and unemployment insurance etc. Employment may not be constant; he will have to feed and clothe himself, buy books and tools and try and give his mother a few dollars a month as well.

It is therefore recommended:
(a) that this boy be allowed to transfer his courses from High School Graduation to a contract apprenticeship of 4 years, at McLeans Shipyard, Prince Rupert.
(b) that he be assisted for the 1st year with a Tuition grant of $360.00 only, and that the apprenticeship be further reviewed in a years time.

Medical exam forms and application for grant are attached herewith, also his High School report card.

March 7th, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources
Ottawa.

Re Credit Voucher #172, $1,750.00, tuition grants. We pay only $45.00 a month for board and room for these High School boys. The regular rate for board and room in Prince Rupert is $50.00 or more. I found that these boys were sleeping on an old double bed with an old mattress not fit for use. The landlady stated she was unable to buy mattresses and single beds unless we raised the rates to at least $50.00 a month. I considered it cheaper to buy the mattresses to go with two single beds which we had in our storage from War Assets stock. This equipment will remain the property of the Department. I later changed the home for these lads and moved the beds and mattresses to the new domicile, where they are much happier.

Sgd. E. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

Re: Gloria Morven, Gitlakdamix Band.

Application is made for a grant of $255.00 to enable Gloria Morven to proceed to Grade 11 in Booth Memorial High School. I attach herewith her school report which shows that she is promoted to Grade 11 in the subjects passed through the year.

In a letter to Mrs. Mabel Morven under date of July 8th, 1949, copy of which was forwarded to you, I informed this girl's mother that she should not expect assistance from the Department in view of her record during the year.

This record has been the subject of considerable investigation and also of several interviews with her mother and other interested Natives as a result of which I am now satisfied that part of the cause of this girl's academic recession last year was due to causes outside of her control. I have discussed her case with the school officials who are of the opinion that under different conditions, Gloria would do alright. She has the intelligence to go ahead as is evidenced by her Grade 9 report in which year she gained 31 credits, 3 more than the required 28. Last year Gloria was at the Salvation Army Hostel where I have now discovered she was the butt of an inter-tribal feud plus a religious problem as between her and the Salvation Army officials. It is my opinion that if she could be placed elsewhere she would make a satisfactory adjustment.

To this end I am arranging for her to stay with an Uncle and Aunt at Port Edward this winter. They offer her a home if the Department will assist with school fees, books and transportation costs by bus. I have had a long talk
with Gloria and believe that she has reached a definite conclusion that under the proposed setup she will make good and proceed to Grade II. She has the ability to make a useful school teacher and I believe that we should not stand in the way of her possible success in this endeavour.

It should be remembered in this case that this girl's father is dead and her mother's ability to earn is limited, by the fact that she is endeavoring to support three children.

The grant of $255.00 is made up of $150.00 for fees, $25.00 for books and $80.00 for bus transportation. The grant is recommended and the Department's instructions will be appreciated.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent

Dear Mr. Perry:

I am writing on behalf of Williamson Walkem, pupil #680, Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, who matriculated from Chilliwack High School a year ago.

At a conference on his case at which were present Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn, Mr. Inspector Barry and the Rev. Principal Lett, he was advised to take his Senior Matriculation at Chilliwack High School, preceding Normal training. He failed to make his year and cannot repeat it at Chilliwack as the Trustees decided not to continue the classes for Senior Matriculation work this year. This places Walkem in a difficult position.

I received a letter a few days ago from Mr. Indian Agent Barber of Merritt, inclosing one from C. Walkem of Spences Bridge, father of the boy, both anxiously inquiring what could be done. Upon receipt of a letter from Capt. Barry which, on account of the probably difficulty of securing a suitable position even if he secured his teacher's certificate, discarded the idea of Normal training, I sent for Walkem to come to see me and talk the matter over concerning his future. He is anxious to repeat the year at the University of British Columbia, assuring me his Father and Brother could and would help him to the extent of $250.00. I would recommend the Department of Indian Affairs make a grant of $250.00. With care he can get through the year on $500.00 including fees, board, and other expenses. I would favor his repeating the year because I believe he will make good. He is not the quiet student Percy Gladstone was but he is a plodder with a great deal of character. He lost no time last year but he is somewhat handicapped by his English, which is apt to be wondered at. His Mother is absolutely illiterate. His father has very little and it is greatly to the credit of this quiet and unassuming Indian boy that he has the ambition to make something of himself. If another trial is not provided for him the affect upon the students who could take further training will be discouraging.

Since the Indians met some years ago, as you will remember, the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Hon. Mr. Stewart, and the Deputy Minister, the matter of advancing training was agreed upon and the manner in which the Department has fulfilled such undertaking is highly creditable, for if ever a race, dependent upon any Government, had a chance to make good along educational lines, that race comprises the native tribes of British Columbia.

Let me again say the boy is deeply in earnest and what I have written is in harmony with the wishes of the staff here and I feel sure that of his former Principal, Rev. A.R. Lett. I believe it would be a good investment on the part of the Department for many reasons to take this action, to make this grant on his behalf.

Yours very truly,

"G.H. Raley"

Sir:

I beg to transmit herewith copies of three letters, dated September 19th, ultimo, October 4th, and 12th, instant, being correspondence between the Principal of Coghataetza Indian Residential School and this office in regard to the proposal to give pupil No.680, Williamson Walzem, an advanced educational training, either at B.C. University in preparation for the teaching profession, or at Vancouver Technical High School in preparation for a career in which a Technical Course would be helpful to him in after life.

The boy Walzem took his Entrance and Junior Matriculation at Chilliwack. He did not take Normal subjects, but tried Senior Matriculation at Chilliwack and failed totally, presumably through lack of essential home work. The Senior Matriculation class at Chilliwack High School has been done away with; and to qualify for Normal the student must either repeat his attempt at a Senior High School elsewhere or take First Year Arts in B.C. University or at Victoria College. The application was received and the boy was admitted to his entrance to either of these Courses. Moreover, the B.C. Education Department objected to the High School Course being taken in some other city; and the Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia—Capt. Barry—is not satisfied that this student, if allowed to take an advanced Course in preparation for the teaching profession, would ever make an efficient teacher. The Inspector felt that he might not be accepted at B.C. Normal School nor recommended for an Indian school.

Sir:

I have the honor to refer to Departmental letter No.103-169, dated October 25th, last, in which authority was given to arrange for the admission to the Technical High School at Vancouver of Indian pupil Williamson Walkem of Coqualeetza Indian Residential School.

In this connection, I beg to say that subsequent arrangements were made with Reverend Principal Raley and Mr. Agent Ball at Vancouver whereby these gentlemen were expected to come together at a convenient date and discuss all phases of the matter and to arrange the details regarding other matters. Copy of my letter dated October 26th addressed, respectively, to Mr. Agent Ball and Rev. G.H. Raley, are enclosed herewith. Subsequently each was also furnished with copy of the Department's letter dated October 25th above mentioned.

It is quite inconvenient as well as unnecessarily expensive for me to go to Vancouver every time a boy is to be admitted to the Technical School, and therefore it was hoped that the Principal and Agent Ball would be in good position to arrange all the details especially as to receipt of the Department's grant to be forwarded by the Agent in Vancouver and also because it is a fact that the Principal of Coqualeetza is frequently in Vancouver purchasing goods and otherwise transmitting business in connection with the School at which times it would be quite easy for the Agent and Principal to meet and discuss the matter of boys attending the Technical School.

Not having heard anything further from the Agent or Principal as to what arrangements were made in Walkem's behalf, I wrote to the Agent on November 28th making inquiry. I received a letter from Mr. Agent Ball dated November 28th, ultimo, copy of this letter is being sent herewith. As a result of this latter I wrote Reverend Mr. Raley to know why the suggestions contained in my letter of October 26th had not been fruitful of good results, and I received reply to the effect that everything possible had been done by him in the matter.

I am satisfied from further inquiry that Walkem had made up his mind to train for the teaching profession for which he could not be recommended by the Inspector of Schools and myself. He agreed to take a technical course but afterwards changed his mind, leaving us with the grant available and unused.

I suggested to Principal Raley that Walkem be given another chance to consider what action he would take and in the meantime asked Agent Ball to hold the grant in abeyance as Walkem may be willing to take the course commencing in January.

Should......
Should Walkem decide not to go to the Technical School, the Department might be asked to transfer the grant for the benefit of another bright pupil—Fred Wilson—who was willing to take Walkem's place and who was strongly recommended by the Principal for this privilege.

Mr. Ball advised me on December 20th, that he had been instructed by the Department to return the cheque "stating that they are in doubt in a number of cases where grants have been provided for young Indians to take courses in technical schools if they use the training received to any advantage." I hope the matter will be reconsidered and restated in the light of the Department's educational policy. It is felt that the time has arrived when there should be a meeting of such Church and Government officials who are most interested in the policies which bear upon the progressive education of the Indian youth of this Province. Such a convention was asked for by resolution of certain school principals held with a few of our officials in Vancouver about a year ago. We do not know what the Department thinks of these resolutions, but I would with such respect suggest that it be kept in view that it is most desirable that a meeting of the kind should be held for the purpose of discussing what phases of Indian educational advancement should be best recommended in British Columbia. I was exceedingly sorry to receive this letter from Agent Ball, and feel that the Agent acted with undue haste in disposing of the matter. Some patience and sympathy must be exercised if we are going to get the best results from our aids to Indians under the General Vote, particularly in regard to the progressive education of the more promising of the ex-pupils of Indian residential schools.

I regret being under the impression that Mr. Agent Ball has not shown sufficiently sympathetic interest in the Indian pupils to be willing to go to any great inconvenience in regard to their advancement along technical lines. I believe the Department should find an earnest investigation among those best versed in Indian Affairs in British Columbia that the provision which has been made for the technical training of the Indian youth promises greater possibilities than any other phase of our aid system. It is the best step ever taken by the Department, in my opinion, for the furthering of the interests of Indian boys who leave school and face a world of realities in which training of this nature counts so much. Such training helps the Indians on their reserves as well as in the competitive fields of labor which their natural ambitions might explore under their right to live in the enjoyment of progressive Canadian citizenship towards which the Indians are becoming more and more inclined through primary training. What is the use of our school system if such a result cannot be achieved?

In addition to the case of Williamson Walkem there is another Indian boy for whom a Departmental grant was made. His name is Cyril Mahone (see authority of Departmental letter No.103-155 dated September 13th last.) In this case I wrote to Agent Ball on September 22nd, copy of my letter to him being enclosed here-with together with his reply dated September 23rd. The Agent's reply should be enough to assure any one that he means that he is on the wrong track if he thinks it unnecessary to discuss with the school principal the case and interests of any ambitious Indian boy who has sufficient snap to make something of his life. If the Agent could come down from his high horse and show a little more willingness...
willingness to bear with a few necessary inconveniences to himself whereby an Indian lad, unaccustomed to the ways of the city could be made to feel more serene in his new found environment, much more good might be accomplished than is at present the case.

The Department's letter as quoted by Mr. Agent Ball, if correct, is most disappointing, and I hope it is not the last decisive word on so vital a question. I feel that the Department may not be in possession of all the facts, hence my appeal.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo with reference to Williamson Walkem.

This lad arrived here on a Sunday evening. I did not see him at any time but understand I called at this office on the following day when I was out of town and the stenographer directed me to the boarding house where he had made arrangements for him to stay. He called there and left his baggage, but returned later in the day and said he could not get the course he wanted at the Technical School and that it was useless for him to attend there. He then took his baggage and returned home. I did not have an opportunity of speaking to him but when I found he had left Vancouver I consulted Reverend Mr. Raley about him and he said he would get in touch with Walkem and let me know what he intended to do. Since then I have heard nothing from Mr. Raley until today, when he informed me that he had written three times and telegraphed once to Walkem who has never replied to any of these communications.

Mr. Raley now advises me that Walkem was working at cross purposes. He wanted to attend normal school and take up teaching as a career, but was disappointed in being unable to do so because he lacked training in two or three necessary subjects which the Coqualeetza School was unable to give him. Mr. Raley thinks that his visit to the Technical School was rather half-hearted, which would explain his sudden return home.

Mr. Raley advises me that he understands Walkem now wants to take the engineering course at the technical school and his letters and telegram were to try and arrange for him to attend the next term course.

I should have been glad to do everything possible to assist Walkem, the same as I have done in a number of similar cases, but did not have the opportunity. I had no idea when he would arrive in Vancouver, but all arrangements were made ready to receive him both at the technical school and boarding house, and I can not quite see where there was any lack of encouragement in Vancouver as stated by Mr. Perry.

Mr. Raley is again trying to get in touch with Walkem and will advise me as to the result, when I will report further to you.

I may say I am in favor of sending promising boys from the Residential Schools to efficient Technical Schools for training provided these pupils are recommended by the School Principal, the Inspector of Indian Schools and the Indian Agent, and for this reason would recommend that the boy Smith Bent be afforded the opportunity which he is seeking of taking a suitable Technical Course in woodcraft and drawing for which he appears to be particularly adapted.

Dear Mr. Lett:

In reply to your letter of the 16th instant, I do not think it advisable to change Smith Bent's boarding house. He is well taken care of and I think we were very fortunate in getting him into such good surroundings.

I allow him $5.00 a month pocket money, which should leave him a good deal more per week, after paying his carfare, than my own boys, going to High School, have to spend.

The Department, it is true, allow $500.00, but that does not mean that we are to expend the whole amount simply to teach this youth a trade or vocation and I personally think he is getting quite as much as is good for him now. Furthermore, it appears to me that when the Department go to such expense to provide training for an Indian youth, that the least his family can do is to make an effort towards his support. It is really too much to expect the Department to finance his board, education, clothing, pocket money and all expenses. The Department in the past has relieved the Indians of too much responsibility, which is probably one of the reasons why so many of them are shiftless now.

I spoke to the Principal of the Trapp Technical School, upon the subject of changing his social studies to a wood-working period. This cannot be done, as these studies are an obligatory part of the course, and no exceptions can be made.

Personally, I do not think that Technical Schools, as they are run, form a satisfactory means of training Indian pupils in advanced craftsmanship, as a comparatively small portion of their time is devoted to the particular art they are desired to acquire.

Smith Bent's periods at wood-working last term only covered the ground he had already been over at St. George's School before coming down here. It appears to me, therefore, that where it is desired to give boys special training in such subjects as wood-working, motor mechanics etc., it would be far better to apprentice or otherwise attach them to some shop where they would have more days' work due to their particular course, instead of two periods a week the Technical School schedule allows them. The academic portion of the Technical School class work is, of course, of no use to the Indians we desire to benefit, especially in cases where they are only getting one year.

Another advantage of this line of action would be that the Indian pupil could be kept more or less in his local environment and placed in some small country town, where he would not be so likely to become accustomed to the glamour of white lights, as in the City.

The boy is doing well, and his last report was extremely satisfactory, but just the same, I think he would have derived far more advantage from a year spent in some wood-working plant than he will obtain from his time at the Technical School.

Yours sincerely,

A.G.M. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

Rev. A.R. Lett,
Principal, St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I have a letter from Smith asking if he can change his boarding house as it is costing so much for street car fare. I am not at all anxious that he should make this change if it can be avoided as he evidently has a good place to stay and his landlady is evidently very good to him and is interested in him.

I do not know what you have spent to date in connection with the lad's course of studies but would suggest that if it is possible at all to increase his monthly allowance and still stay within the grant, this should be done. However, if you feel this is impossible it would be well to get into touch with Mr. Douker, soliciting his help. Please do what you think best.

Smith has also written about his period in social studies asking if he could perhaps take woodwork instead, if this can be arranged with the principal I think it would be a good move as Smith is not up in his social studies, taking for his entrance examinations art instead. There is no possibility of the boy taking any more government examinations and training is all that he is expected to have. Please get into touch with the principal regarding this matter.

Yours very sincerely,

Dear Mr. Lett:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated the 25th instant, with reference to Smith Bent. Student's car tickets for this youth are forty (40) for $1.00, good up until five o'clock, and as he is in School on an average of twenty-two (22) days a month, $1.00 practically covers his legitimate needs, he has, therefore, close on a $1.00 a week to provide extra transportation to night classes.

It appears to me that to supply him freely with money, would merely mean an inducement to shirk his studies. You must remember that we pay for his board, laundry, clothing and books, so the only legitimate expense he is called upon for, is the transportation above alluded to, and in view of the given figures, I fail to see how you can make out that this cost should be more than the $5.00 a month I am giving him.

I would like to point out also, that my boys are in a different position to Smith Bent, and while they may not have much expenditure for carfare, they have social obligations that far exceed his.

I am surprised at your attitude in the matter, as you must know that any youth turned loose in a City, with unlimited cash, is open to grave temptations.

I am, however, forwarding your communication to the Department, and will be guided by their instructions, as to the amount of pocket money Smith is to receive.

Yours sincerely,

Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Daunt,

I do not wish to go into your letter in detail but wish you would consider again the amt of $5.00 as a monthly allowance for Smith. I think a little figuring will show you that if he travels by street car to and from his school it would take more than the stated sum to cover this expense so that it would seem he is obliged to spend some time walking which walking time he would very much like to spend in study. There should be no question of extravagance taken into consideration as the lad merely asked for a little greater monthly allowance in order that he might make better use of his time. If it is therefore possible without overstepping try and consider his needs.

When in the city last I did take up the fact that Smith could take more advanced work in woodwork and drafting and he told me at Christmas that this was forthcoming, and I expect this is now being done. You might make enquiries to this effect if you will and let me know.

As you live in the centre of the city I do not think a comparison should be made between your own Boys and Smith.

You have touched up your views a bit but let me ask if you have ever spent some of your off time in putting these into writing when they could be compared with others especially men like myself whose heart and soul bleeds for these peoples.

As for the Lads parents being able to offer any assistance I do not think they readily can but if you would wish further information in this regard write Mr. Barber at Merritt.

Also I am asking for on behalf of the Lad and at his own request a little extra consideration in order that he might make better use of his time. I shall be glad to hear from Smith that you have been able to do so.

I appreciate the Principal's inability to rearrange the study hour or period.

Since the Dept. has no schools wherein these Boys can receive training for which they are qualified then surely it remains for you and I to do the best possible with the confidence the Dept. has placed in us and also for the Boy concerned. It is not the saving of a few poultry dollars but the training of a Boy who with it may not only take care of himself but be an example to many others of his race.

Yours very sincerely

[Signature]
Principal
SIR:-

With further reference to my letter of January 24th, under cover of which I forwarded you a communication received from the Reverend A.R. Lett, Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School, in connection with Smith Bent, Indian pupil of the Nicola Agency, attending the Trapp Technical School of this City.

I now beg to enclose herewith, a further letter in this connection, and I shall be much obliged if you will inform me whether it is your desire that I increase the issue of pocket money to this youth.

So far as the contents of the letter are concerned, I would like to point out that Smith Bent can purchase forty (40) student's street car tickets for $1.00. As he attends school about average on twenty-two (22) days per month, this expenditure practically clears his necessity in attending his usual classes while leaving him the sum of $4.00 in hand. On two nights a week, however, he attends extra classes for motor mechanics, but I consider the $4.00 is ample to cover this extra expenditure, as we have provided him with clothes and books and pay his laundry with his board. There is, therefore, nothing for him to spend the money on, and I personally think he is getting sufficient. Any youth turned loose in a city, will find what he has in his pocket, and an Indian, even though he is a good one like Smith, is certainly no better than a white boy in this respect.

In my view, we would not be assisting Smith in his studies, as indicated by Reverend Mr. Lett, in giving him any more spending money, but on the contrary we would be giving him the means to neglect his studies. I may, however, be wrong, and I shall be very much obliged if you will let me have your instructions at your early convenience.

I know Indians practically, for the last twenty-one years in the service of the Department and for a considerable time before that, and if I am to be in charge of this youth, while he is down here, I do not think that Reverend Mr. Lett should interfere on the representations of the Indian.

Reverend Mr. Lett does not seem to appreciate that City Technical Schools have to be run according to standard rules and regulations, and that when a boy enters a class, he must stay with that class and follow its work, he cannot be given special tuition. The Authorities will not do this for the children of City taxpayers, and naturally they will not do it for Indians from outside points. I have spoken to the Principal of the Technical School and he has pointed this out to me.

Enclos.

Your obedient servant,

A.G.M. Daunt.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, Indian Agent.

I have your letter dated Feb. 6th and numbering 103-169 regarding the correspondence between Mr. Daunt and myself about the help which Smith Bent asked for which we assist him to give more time to his studies. This is a reasonable request from the lad as he lives some three miles away from school and his street car fare is costing him 85¢ per week.

I might say that it was through the advice of Mr. Daunt's office that the boy wrote to me asking for advice. I then asked Mr. Daunt to consider his requests. However while I do not feel the boy received a real sympathetic hearing, I will advise Smith Bent to be governed entirely by Mr. Daunt. It does seem as though the boy should be allowed to seek advice from one who has been responsible for his care for a great number of years and cutting off this source is not very encouraging.

Yours very obediently,

A. R. Lett,
Principal.

SIR:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your telegram, dated the 17th, instant, reading as follows:

"There is balance twenty eight dollars and fifty cents outstanding in connection with advance made you for tuition of Smith Dent.stop. Please account for this amount at once."

To this I replied today:

"Your wire seventeenth.stop. Account Smith Bent closed June thirtieth by Draft Receiver General for twenty two ten.stop. Statement being mailed."

I am, therefore, enclosing herewith, Statement showing the operation of this Advance from October 11th, 1933, to date of Draft No. 31, in favour of the Receiver General, for Twenty two dollars and ten cents, on June 30th, 1934, closing out the balance at credit, according to our Records at that date.

Each month, during the life of the Advance, a Statement, supported by Vouchers, and the cancelled cheques, was forwarded the Department, and no comments received.

In my letter of July 3rd, 1934, covering the Agency Financial statements for June, the following paragraph appears:

"A Statement supported by Vouchers, in connection with expenditures from the Departmental Advance on account of Smith Bent, Nicola Agency, ex-pupil of St. George's Indian Residential School, who has attended the Technical School in this city, is passed for your information, together with Bank Draft No. 31, for $22.10, clearing the balance of cash on hand, as the youth has completed the school year, and returned to his Reserve."

No comment was received from this either.

As a matter of fact, the Department really owes me $5.85, which I advanced in April 1934, to balance the amount of bills owing, when you failed to forward the Advance asked for. However, I let the matter go.

Dear Mr. Barber,

I have Edith Walkem, Pupil No.0122 of this School, who is in her Junior Matriculation year and is a girl who intends to proceed with her studies to Senior Matric and then on to Normal. I would recommend her to you for any assistance she may need in this regard.

Her family, as you know, for Indians are very much better in a position to help her than many white families but, being Indians, (and especially from this family the expectation that the Dept. should undertake full liability) I do not expect she will receive help to any great extent from this source. You may, however, be able to induce from them some assistance for the girl.

In conversation with Edith, she is very anxious that, if possible, she should, at least to a degree, be found sufficient employment to enable her to finance her own advanced education, which is a very admirable inclination and I may be able to make some provision for her to carry out her feeling. I am, however, laying her case before you and have no hesitancy in writing what, in conversation, I told you some few days ago, that I very strongly recommend her advance and assistance if needed.

If there is any information you may need on her behalf, I shall be glad to give it to you.

Yours very sincerely,

A.R. Lett

Principal
Dear Mr. Lett:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, in regard to Edith Walkem, and have noted your remarks and recommendation that any necessary assistance be given to her to enable her to continue her studies through to Normal.

I would suggest that at a later date, when it is assured that she will pass her Junior Matriculation, that you write me again making a definite suggestion as to the manner in which she could be assisted.

As you state, her family, as Indians, are much better able to assist this girl than many white families, and I would not recommend that the Department bear all the expense of putting the girl through Normal. But, would recommend that any assistance her family are prepared to give her, be supplemented by the Department, perhaps on a half share basis.

However, as you know, I am not in a position at this time to give any definite assurance that the Department would agree.

I think that if you are of the opinion that Edith is capable of going through Normal, and would justify the expense of the Department giving the necessary assistance, and that she will not want to quit and get married (?) in a year or so, that Inspector Harry be also requested to make a recommendation on her behalf.

Please write me again in this regard at the end of the school year, when I will take the matter up with the Department.

Regarding employment for Edith, I only wish I could assure her of this, but am sorry that in so far as my Agency is concerned, there is little likelihood of anything but the usual work available to the Indian girls, in the fields or working for a crew on a ranch cooking, and even these jobs are few and far between.

Yours truly,

Rev. Mr. A.R. Lett, Principal,
St. George's Indian Res. School,
Lyton B.C.

Dear Mr. Barber:

Again regarding the further education of Edith Walkem, I might say that I have no doubt at all in my mind that the girl will qualify in her examinations for Senior matric. and is very well up in her work.

At the last inspection of the School by Capt. Barry, I spoke to him of her work here and approached him, as you suggested, regarding her future and understand he spoke to you stating that he had nothing to do with any advanced education and that the proposition was entirely in the hands of the Principal and the Agent. I think it would be well, therefore, for the question to be taken up with the Dept. at an early date, suggesting that they be prepared to assist this girl.

Charlie Walkem, the father, was here a week last Sunday and, I understand, wished to see me but as I was unavoidably absent from the School, I have not heard further from him. I understood from Edith that her father wished to see me at your suggestion and I expect he will probably be sympathetic towards helping.

I made enquiries through the Secretary of the High School Board at Chililwack and find that there is a fee of $10.00 per month charged to all Senior matriculants and I have also taken up the possibility of Edith being able to work for her Board, and it may be that I shall be able to arrange for her Senior Matric year with very little expense to the Department. Dear Sir:

I beg to forward herewith copies of correspondence between this office and Reverend A.R. Lett, Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton B.C., in regard to his recommendation that assistance be granted by the Department to enable Pupil No. 0122 - Edith Walkem - to continue her studies through Senior Matriculation.

This girl will pass her Junior Matriculation this year, and I am informed that she desires to obtain further education, with intention of becoming a teacher. My views in this regard are expressed in my letter to Mr. Lett, dated April 17th, a copy of which is hereto attached.

I have spoken to Charlie Walkem, father of this girl, who is a member of the Cook's Ferry Band of this Agency, in this regard, but at the time he did not care to commit himself, until after he had had an opportunity to discuss the matter with his daughter Edith.

Walkem has been in steady employment on the railway as section man for many years; and in addition has a very nice small ranch and a number of cattle. He is also able to operate a car bought a few years ago, and with the exception that he lives on the Indian Reserve and is a member of the Band, leads the life of an average white wage earner, and is in a position to bear part of the cost of any advanced education his daughter receives.

Should this girl qualify for a position as teacher, I wonder what opportunity would arise for her to obtain a position. Further, I find that these girls, on leaving the Residential School, appear only too anxious to find a husband(?) .

However, Edith is a nice girl, and Mr. Lett recommends her highly, and I would also like to recommend that the Department make a grant to enable her to take her Senior Matriculation providing her father will be agreeable to pay $10.00 or $15.00 per month towards the cost.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 31st ultimo, regarding the claims for a tuition grant of the above noted pupil.

I note with interest that the circumstances of this pupil's parents are comparatively good and that they should be in a position to contribute to the education of their daughter. In view of this fact, the Department is prepared to pay the actual tuition costs of the girl, should she decide to proceed with her high school course at Chilliwack. This grant will be subject to the approval of Inspector Barry, to whom this case should be referred, and will be made on the understanding that the parents of the girl assume responsibility for her board and lodging.

It is just possible that the Principal of the School might be able to place this girl in a home at Chilliwack, where she could do a certain amount of work in return for her board and lodging. In any event, the Department is not prepared to pay more than the actual tuition costs. It is noted that these costs amount to $10.00 per month.

Yours truly,

June 11, 1948.

Mr. G. Sharp, Indian Agent
Merrit B.C.

Dear Sir,

Received my Examination Results Yesterday. I passed with a supplement in Chemistry. I plan to take summer School commencing July 5th, to offset this Chemistry and an English course. This would not be possible for the Department to assist me in my goal. As I feel I shall not earn a satisfactory amount during this summer to tide me over the irregular winter session.

The amount of assistance I shall need is:
Instruction fees etc. $40.00
Books $25.00
Room & Board $75.00
Total $140.00

If this amount of money is at all possible will you let me know. I feel certain that I know with your cooperation and help I shall go to Summer School.

Yours truly,
Clarence Walker
Nicola Indian Agency,
Merritt, B.C.
June 15th, 1948.

W.S. Arneil, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Vancouver, B.C.

RE:- Clarence WALKER, Cook's Ferry Band.
Summer School.

I am enclosing this boy's letter which is self explanatory.

I have been rather proud of this boy and hope for good results from him as he is very earnest in his work. This is the end of his second year and I do hope he can be given the extra assistance he asks for. His family have been working hard to make the University possible.

Our Department also has been a great factor in the scheme. I believe the boy well worth the help.

If you would care to write to him personally it would be very much appreciated.

G. E. Sharpe,
Superintendent.

Re: Tuition Grant - Clarence Walkem

Attached herewith is an application from the above mentioned, along with a letter from Superintendent Sharpe in support of this application.

This student has been carrying supplemental work for the last two years and with the exception of this has been successful in both his first and second year work at the University.

It is recommended that this application be approved in order to permit Mr. Walkem to commence his third year work without the handicap of having to complete these two subjects.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
AIR MAIL

July 13, 1948.

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We have received your letter of the 6th instant, file 9-11-1, regarding Clarence Walkem.

His request is rather unusual but in view of the strong recommendation made by the Indian Superintendent and Inspector Davey, it has been decided to allow him a tuition grant not exceeding $140.00 for the special course that he is taking this summer.

We do not see the necessity for $25.00 for books as it is presumed that he must have had the books for the subjects mentioned.

Bernard F. Neary
